API Documentation#

DirectoryManager#

The clustersort pipeline manages directories for 2 primary purposes:

  • an entrypoint for the data being sorted

  • a place to store plots and temporary data files

Both of these use cases are handled via the DirectoryManager.

Example

from clustersort import DirectoryManager as dm
from clustersort import SpkConfig as config
# create a directory manager
dm = dm('path/to/data', 'path/to/output')

# create a configuration object
config = config()

# set the parameters
config.n_channels = 32
config.n_features = 3
config.n_clusters = 5

# save the configuration
config.save(dm.config_path)
class clustersort.DirectoryManager(filepath: str | Path)

Manages directories for storing processed data, plots, reports, and intermediate files.

Note

Several temporary and permanent directories must be made so save plotting results, and to store data used to create those plots.

property channel

Channel index incremented by 1.

Type:

int

create_base_directories()

Creates the base directories for raw data, processed data, plots, reports, and temporary files.

create_channel_directories(num_chan)

Creates a set of subdirectories for a specific channel under each base directory.

Parameters:

num_chan (int) – Number of channels for which to create directories.

flush_directories()

Deletes all files and subdirectories in each base directory.

Raises:

Exception – If there is an error in deleting files or directories.

property intermediate

Directory for storing intermediate files.

Type:

Path

property plots

Directory for storing plots.

Type:

Path

property processed

Directory for storing processed data.

Type:

Path

property reports

Directory for storing reports.

Type:

Path

SpkConfig#

For the actual sorting, there are a variety of paramters that can be tuned based on the type of data the user is working with. This is managed by SpkConfig. These parameters are covered in detail in the configuration guide.

class clustersort.SpkConfig(cfg_path: Path | str = '')

Initialize a new SpkConfig object to manage configurations for the clustersort pipeline.

This class reads from an INI-style configuration file and provides methods to access the configurations for different sections. These sections include ‘run’, ‘path’, ‘cluster’, and so on.

Parameters:

config_path (str or Path, optional) – The path to the configuration file. Defaults to a pre-defined location.

Notes

The configuration file is an INI-style file with the following sections:

  • run: dict

    Contains configurations related to runtime settings like ‘resort-limit’, ‘cores-used’

  • pathdict

    Contains path settings like directories for run, ‘results’.

  • clusterdict

    Contains clustering parameters like ‘max-clusters’, ‘max-iterations’.

  • breachdict

    Contains breach analysis parameters like ‘disconnect-voltage’, ‘max-breach-rate’.

  • filterdict

    Contains filter parameters like ‘low-cutoff’, ‘high-cutoff’.

  • spikedict

    Contains spike-related settings like ‘pre-time’, ‘post-time’.

Note

Due to the nature of INI files, all values are stored as strings. It is up to the user to convert the values to the appropriate type.

Examples

>>> cfg = SpkConfig()
>>> run = cfg.run
>>> print(type(run), run)
<class 'dict'> {'resort-limit': '3', 'cores-used': '8', ...}

>>> cfg.set('run', 'resort-limit', 5)
>>> print(cfg.run['resort-limit'])
'5'

See Also: configparser from python std library

property breach

returns: A dictionary containing key-value pairs for the ‘breach’ section. :rtype: dict

property cluster

Get a dictionary containing all key: value pairs for the cluster section.

Returns:

A dictionary containing key-value pairs for the ‘cluster’ section.

Return type:

dict

property detection

returns: A dictionary containing key-value pairs for the ‘detection’ section. :rtype: dict

property filter

returns: A dictionary containing key-value pairs for the ‘breach’ section. :rtype: dict

get_all()

Get a dictionary of key: value pairs for every section, conglomerated.

Returns:

A dictionary containing all key-value pairs from all sections.

Return type:

dict

get_section(section: str)

Returns a dictionary containing key-value pairs for the given section.

Parameters:

section (str) – The name of the section in the config file.

Returns:

Dictionary containing the section’s key-value pairs.

Return type:

dict

property path

Get a dictionary containing all key: value pairs for the path section.

The path section stores paths for the plots and data produced and used by the clustersorting pipeline.

Returns:

A dictionary containing key-value pairs for the ‘path’ section.

Return type:

dict

property pca

returns: A dictionary containing key-value pairs for the ‘pca’ section. :rtype: dict

property postprocess

returns: A dictionary containing key-value pairs for the ‘postprocess’ section. :rtype: dict

read_config()
Returns:

A ConfigParser object loaded with the INI file.

Return type:

ConfigParser

property run

Get a dictionary containing all key: value pairs for the run section.

Returns:

A dictionary containing key-value pairs for the ‘run’ section.

Return type:

dict

set(section: str, key: str, value: Any)

Set the value of a configuraton parameter.

Parameters:

  • section (str) – The section of the paremeter being set.

  • key (str) – The key of the section to be set.

  • value (str) – The value being set by the user.

Returns:

  • None

  • .. note:: – All parts of the configuration, section, key and value, are strings. This is how configparser works under the hood. It is up to the user to convert datatypes when needed.

set_config(default=False)
Parameters:

default (bool, optional) – If True, sets the configuration to its default settings. Defaults to False.

set_default_config() → None

Sets the default configurations for all sections. Writes these to the configuration file.

property spike

returns: A dictionary containing key-value pairs for the ‘spike’ section. :rtype: dict
